item.title: Rachel add a quote by Alain de Botton
item.description: "Every adult life could be said to be defined by two great love stories. The first—the story of our quest for sexual love—is well known and well charted, its vagaries form the staple of music and literature, it is socially accepted and celebrated. The second—the story of our quest for love from the world—is a more secret and shameful tale." -- Alain de Botton

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Susan Sontag
item.description: "Attention is vitality. It connects you with others. It makes you eager. Stay eager." -- Susan Sontag

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Ray Bradbury
item.description: "The books are to remind us what asses and fools we are." -- Ray Bradbury

item.title: Rachel add a quote by David Mikics
item.description: "The digital world offers us many advantages, but if we yield to that world too completely we may lose the privacy we need to develop a self. Activities that require time and careful attention, like serious reading, are at risk; we read less and skim more as the Internet occupies more of our lives." -- David Mikics

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "Curiosity is only vanity. We usually only want to know something so that we can talk about it." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Mark Sisson
item.description: "A US study showed that rats exposed to invisible television rays (screen was blackened) for six hours per day became hyperactive and extremely aggressive for about a week, then suddenly become totally lethargic and stopped breeding entirely." -- Mark Sisson

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "We run carelessly over the precipice after having put something in front of us to prevent us seeing it." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "All of humanity's problems stem from man's inability to sit quietly in a room alone." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "I would prefer an intelligent hell to a stupid paradise." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "When one does not love too much, one does not love enough." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "Little things comfort us because little things distress us." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "When I see the blind and wretched state of men, when I survey the whole universe in its deadness, and man left to himself with no light, as though lost in this corner of the universe without knowing who put him there, what he has to do, or what will become of him when he dies, incapable of knowing anything, I am moved to terror, like a man transported in his sleep to some terrifying desert island, who wakes up quite lost, with no means of escape. Then I marvel that so wretched a state does not drive people to despair." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Blaise Pascal
item.description: "The more I see of Mankind, the more I prefer my dog." -- Blaise Pascal

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Viktor Emil Frankl
item.description: "To draw an analogy: a man's suffering is similar to the behavior of a gas. If a certain quantity of gas is pumped into an empty chamber, it will fill the chamber completely and evenly, no matter how big the chamber. Thus suffering completely fills the human soul and conscious mind, no matter whether the suffering is great or little. Therefore the "size" of human suffering is absolutely relative." -- Viktor Emil Frankl

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Jean-Paul Sartre
item.description: "If you're lonely when you're alone, you're in bad company." -- Jean-Paul Sartre

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Albert Camus
item.description:
"In order to understand the world, one has to turn away from it on occasion."
[<i>The Minotaur</i>]" -- Albert Camus

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "I live in that solitude which is painful in youth, but delicious in the years of maturity." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Ralph Waldo Emerson
item.description: "Guard well your spare moments. They are like uncut diamonds. Discard them and their value will never be known. Improve them and they will become the brightest gems in a useful life." -- Ralph Waldo Emerson

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Arthur Schopenhauer
item.description: "A man can be himself only so long as he is alone; and if he does not love solitude, he will not love freedom; for it is only when he is alone that he is really free." -- Arthur Schopenhauer

item.title: Rachel add a quote by John Milton
item.description: "Solitude sometimes is best society." -- John Milton

item.title: Rachel add a quote by May Sarton
item.description: "Loneliness is the poverty of self; solitude is richness of self." -- May Sarton

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Proust-M
item.description: "Reading is that fruitful miracle of a communication in the midst of solitude." -- Proust-M

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Anthony Burgess
item.description: "To be left alone is the most precious thing one can ask of the modern world." -- Anthony Burgess

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Criss Jami
item.description: "A lonely day is God's way of saying that he wants to spend some quality time with you." -- Criss Jami

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Henri J.M. Nouwen
item.description: "As soon as we are alone,...inner chaos opens up in us. This chaos can be so disturbing and so confusing that we can hardly wait to get busy again. Entering a private room and shutting the door, therefore, does not mean that we immediatel;y shut ou all our iner doubts, anxieities, fears, bad memories, unresolved conflicts, angry feelings and impulsive desires. On the contrary, when we have removed our outer distraction, we often find that our inner distraction manifest themselves to us in full force. We often use the outer distractions to shield ourselves from the interior noises. This makes the discipline of solitude all the more important." -- Henri J.M. Nouwen

item.title: Rachel add a quote by George Gordon Byron
item.description: "Then stirs the feeling infinite, so felt In solitude, where we are <i>least</i> alone." -- George Gordon Byron

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Iris Murdoch
item.description: "I hate solitude, but I'm afraid of intimacy. The substance of my life is a private conversation with myself which to turn into a dialogue would be equivalent to self-destruction. The company which I need is the company which a pub or a cafe will provide. I have never wanted a communion of souls. It's already hard enough to tell the truth to oneself." -- Iris Murdoch

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "I need solitude for my writing; not 'like a hermit' - that wouldn't be enough - but like a dead man." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Rollo May
item.description: "Many people suffer from the fear of finding oneself alone, and so they don't find themselves at all." -- Rollo May

item.title: Rachel add a quote by Patricia Highsmith
item.description: "My imagination functions much better when I don't have to speak to people." -- Patricia Highsmith
